policy_name: "All inclusive" Feed-in Tariff for small renewable energy power plants Italy (2008)
policy_title: "All inclusive" Feed-in Tariff for small renewable energy power plants
policy_instrument: Feed-in tariffs or premiums, Green certificates
policy_description:
The Decree of 11 April 2008 lays down the criteria to stimulate the production of electricity from solar thermodynamic plants, including the hybrid ones, connected to the electricity grid, built in Italy. Plants must be equipped with thermal accumulation systems. On top of the selling price, net electricity produced by thermodynamic solar plants commissioned after 18 July 2008 can obtain a feed-in premium for 25 years. Up to 2012 the bonus varies from EUR 0.22 to EUR 0.28 / kWh depending on the level of integration of the plants. In case of hybrid plants, the feed-in tariff decreases depending on the ratio between the amount of energy not produced by a solar energy source and the amount produced by a solar energy source. The maximum cumulative power of all solar thermodynamic plants eligible for the incentives corresponds to 1.5 million m2 of cumulative surface. The national objective of total power to be installed by 2016 corresponds to 2 million m2 of cumulative surface. For the 2013-2014 period such bonus values will be reduced by 2% a year; from 2014 onward special Ministerial Decree will define further cuts.
IEA/IRENA Global Renewable Energy Policies and Measures Database © OECD/IEA and IRENA, [November 2020]
who_is_impacted: The policy impacts companies that are involved in the production of electricity from solar thermodynamic plants, including hybrid ones, in Italy. These companies must have plants equipped with thermal accumulation systems and connected to the electricity grid. The policy specifically affects those companies whose thermodynamic solar plants were commissioned after 18 July 2008. In the case of hybrid plants, the policy impacts companies depending on the ratio between the amount of energy not produced by a solar energy source and the amount produced by a solar energy source.
key_requirements:
The key requirements of this policy are:

1. The production of electricity must be from solar thermodynamic plants, including hybrid ones, built in Italy.
2. Plants must be equipped with thermal accumulation systems.
3. The net electricity produced by thermodynamic solar plants commissioned after 18 July 2008 can obtain a feed-in premium for 25 years.
4. The bonus varies from EUR 0.22 to EUR 0.28 / kWh depending on the level of integration of the plants up to 2012.
5. In case of hybrid plants, the feed-in tariff decreases depending on the ratio between the amount of energy not produced by a solar energy source and the amount produced by a solar energy source.
6. The maximum cumulative power of all solar thermodynamic plants eligible for the incentives corresponds to 1.5 million m2 of cumulative surface.
7. The national objective of total power to be installed by 2016 corresponds to 2 million m2 of cumulative surface.
8. For the 2013-2014 period, bonus values will be reduced by 2% a year.
9. From 2014 onward, a special Ministerial Decree will define further cuts.
timeline_of_policy_implementation: The policy was implemented starting from the Decree of 11 April 2008. The feed-in premium for net electricity produced by thermodynamic solar plants commissioned after 18 July 2008 is applicable for 25 years. Up to 2012, the bonus varied depending on the level of integration of the plants. For the 2013-2014 period, the bonus values were reduced by 2% a year and from 2014 onward, further cuts were defined by a special Ministerial Decree. The national objective of total power to be installed was set for 2016.

policy_name: "Energy of the Future" monitoring process Germany (2011)
policy_instrument: Policy support, Institutional creation, Strategic planning
policy_description: At the heart of the monitoring process for the energy transition is the Monitoring Report, which is published on an annual basis. The purpose of this report is to condense the reams of statistical information on energy that have been collected into a smaller, more manageable number of selected indicators. This information provides a fact-based overview of the current status of progress with regard to implementation of the energy reforms. The main source of this data is official energy statistics.
policy_type: Energy service demand reduction and resource efficiency, Energy efficiency, Renewables, Non-energy use, Other low-carbon technologies and fuel switch
who_is_impacted: The policy does not specify particular companies that are impacted. However, it involves the monitoring of energy transition, so it would likely impact companies in the energy sector, including those involved in renewable energy, fossil fuels, and energy production and distribution. It could also potentially impact companies that rely heavily on energy for their operations. The policy also mentions the use of data from the Federal Network Agency, the Federal Environment Agency, the Federal Motor Transport Authority, the German Institute for Economic Research, and Statistik der Kohlenwirtschaft, implying that these organizations are also involved in the process.
key_requirements:
The key requirements of this policy include:

1. Continuous monitoring of the energy transition process to track progress, assess measures already implemented, and identify areas needing further efforts.
2. Analysis and condensation of statistical information on energy into an easy-to-understand format.
3. Publication of an annual Monitoring Report providing an overview of the energy transition and its current stage.
4. Involvement of an independent commission of energy experts who provide advice for the drafting process and a scientific opinion on the Monitoring Report.
5. Publication of a Progress Report every three years, providing a wider overview of the energy transition and allowing for deeper analysis over a longer period of time.
6. Use of energy-related statistics as the main source of data for the monitoring process, with data supplied by various federal agencies and research institutes.
7. Public accessibility of the data in electronic form on the website of the Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy and the Federal Network Agency.
8. Revision of the Energy Statistics Act to adapt to the current situation on the national and international energy markets.
timeline_of_policy_implementation: The policy implementation is an ongoing process with annual and triennial reports. The Monitoring Report is published annually, providing an update on the progress achieved in the preceding year. Additionally, every three years, a Progress Report is published to provide a wider overview of the energy transition and deeper analysis over a longer period of time. The first Progress Report was published on 3 December 2014. The exact timeline for future reports is not specified in the policy.

policy_name: "Energy-efficient Systems in Trade and Industry” campaign Germany (2004)
policy_title: "Energy-efficient Systems in Trade and Industry” campaign
who_is_impacted: The policy impacts over 1,000 electricity providers. Specific companies are not mentioned in the policy.
key_requirements:
The key requirements of this policy include:

1. Regular comparison of electricity tariffs: Consumers can find cheaper rates and significantly reduce their monthly electricity costs.
2. Variety of tariffs: The market offers a variety of electricity tariffs with different conditions, terms and additional services. A comparison allows consumers to find the tariff that best suits their individual needs.
3. New customer bonuses: Many electricity providers offer attractive bonuses for new customers. A switch allows consumers to benefit from these offers and receive additional advantages.
4. Price guarantees: Some electricity providers offer price guarantees for a certain period. This means that electricity costs remain stable during this time, regardless of
timeline_of_policy_implementation: The policy does not provide a specific timeline for its implementation. It appears to be an ongoing policy with continuous updates and adjustments based on market conditions and consumer needs.

policy_description: As part of the "Investment for the Future” programme, ADEME (Agence de l'Environnement et de la Maîtrise de l'Énergie - Environment and Energy Management Agency) supports electromobility through a fund dedicated to local authorities willing to deploy charging infrastructure for Plug-in vehicles. The programme was ended in December 2015. IEA/IRENA Global Renewable Energy Policies and Measures Database © OECD/IEA and IRENA, [November 2020]
policy_type: Other low-carbon technologies and fuel switch
who_is_impacted: The policy does not specify particular companies. However, it impacts local authorities willing to deploy charging infrastructure for Plug-in vehicles. Therefore, companies involved in the production and distribution of electric vehicles, as well as those involved in the development and installation of charging infrastructure, could potentially be affected by this policy.
key_requirements:
The key requirements of this policy are:
1. It is part of the "Investment for the Future" program.
2. It is managed by ADEME.
3. It supports electromobility through a fund dedicated to local authorities.
4. The local authorities must be willing to deploy charging infrastructure for Plug-in vehicles.
5. The fund has already financed fifteen projects representing more than 5,000 charging points.
6. The policy was renewed on July 17th, 2014 and ended on December 31st, 2015.
timeline_of_policy_implementation: The "Investment for the Future" program was renewed on July 17th, 2014 and ended on December 31st, 2015.

policy_name: "Kids ISO 14000 Program" for Energy Conservation and GHG Reduction Republic of Korea (2005)
policy_title: "Kids ISO 14000 Program" for Energy Conservation and GHG Reduction
sector: Electricity and heat, Buildings, Hot water and cooking, Appliances
who_is_impacted: The policy does not specify any particular companies or industries that it impacts. It appears to be a general website error message that could potentially affect any company with a website.
key_requirements:
The key requirements of this policy are not explicitly stated as it is a 404 - Page not found policy. However, it does provide three options for users when they encounter this issue: 
1. Return where you came from 
2. Go back 
3. Search for the page again.
timeline_of_policy_implementation: The policy does not provide information on the timeline of its implementation.

policy_description: This programme aims at helping low-income individuals and households to renovate their housings in order to make them more energy efficient and better isolated. The subsidy has an upper limit of 20,000€ per flat/house on a 5 year period. People who do not qualify for this scheme can apply for the Energy Transition Tax Credit (CITE): http://climatepolicydatabase.org/index.php/The_Energy_Transition_Tax_Credit_(CITE)
who_is_impacted: The policy specifically mentions Dila, the publisher of the site Service-Public.fr, and its partners. These are the companies that are impacted by this policy.
key_requirements:
The key requirements of this policy are:
1. The use of cookies to visualize content and improve site functionality through navigation statistics.
2. The Dila (publisher of the site Service-Public.fr) and its partners will deposit these cookies on your terminal during your navigation if you click on "Accept".
3. If you click on "Refuse", these cookies will not be deposited.
4. Your choice is kept for 6 months.
5. You can be informed and modify your preferences at any time on the "Manage cookies" page.
timeline_of_policy_implementation: The policy does not provide a specific timeline for its implementation. However, it does mention that your choice regarding cookies is stored for a period of 6 months.
